paper_abstract: Computer software similarities play important roles in users 'skills transfer from one application to another Despite common software attributes recognized in extant literature, a systematic understanding of the components and structure of software similarities has not been fully developed. To address the issue, a Delphi study was conducted to explore the underlying dimensions of software similarities. Inputs gathered from 20 experienced Information Systems instructors show that Computer Software Similarity is a multi-dimensional construct made up of interface similarity, function similarity, and syntax similarity. Each dimension consists of software attributes that users perceive to be transferable in learning new applications. A field study was carried out to test the impact of the construct. Results from a survey on students' learning two software applications confirm the expectation that Computer Software Similarity facilitates the students' skills transfer between the applications. These studies provide a basis to better design training programs for improved training performance.
paper_title: Exploring the Dimensions and Effects of Computer Software Similarities in Computer Skills Transfer
